rawDocs.text: Dear Ben,
My letter also was written very hastily. We have been very
subject to air raids. Five bombers almost crashed into this house,

They just missed; but I find it 
                  diffiult
                  difficult
                 to concentrate; and
no doubt misinterpreted what you said.  though I didnt mean to.
To be frank, I doubt if I've got your meaning in your last letter.
But I would like to understand your point of view and if possible

make clear my own; so I answer, in the hope 
                  thta
                  that
                 the 
                  iren
                  [iron?]
                 will remain
silent.
You say you dont wish any one to give up painting writing or

thinking about art and 
                  litetrure
                  literature
                . But for some reason Roger Fry
did this in the wrong way. You mean to go on doing it yourself

when the wars over. My 
                   uarrel
                  quarrel
                 
                  yoy
                  you
                 say is not with art but with
Bloomsbury." But what is Bloomsbury? It means, as far as I can see,
a set of people vho sat on the floor at Bernard Street
saying "more and more I understand nothing of humanity in the mass

and were content with that instead of trying to make 
                  h manity
                  humanity
                 in the
mass understand and appreciate what you knew and saw"
Who is "you" in that passage? Do you mean I take it that you mean
me in the first place; and to that I reply, I never said anything
of the kind. I quoted Rogers saying; I also quoted his saying,
Am I responsible for all that Roger said Then I am also responsible

for his saying, More and more [I] dread 
                  impirsonment
                  imprisonment
                 in the

the imprisonment of 
                  egotims
                  egotism
                ; I am also responsible for
teaching the elementary school children [in] the black country
how to draw. I am also responsible for his attempt to make art

enjoyed by the 
                   ublic
                  public
                 in Southwark. In fact I am not
any thing Roger did or said. About 150 was spent on my education.
Letter.
You will complain very justly that this brittle and

im rfect
                  imperfect
                 sketch is only with all its 
                       
                  exeggerations
                  exaggerations
                ,
foreshortenings and is a thing but a gives you nothing
of the emotion which is presumably to be found

in the books 
                  themslves
                  themselves
                .

Here then let us make a 
                  transiton
                  transition
                 from

one kind of reader to another. In order to 
                  divezt
                  divest
                 
                  ourslves
                  ourselves

of the attitude which 
                  Letxus
                  lets us
                 make certain confessions.
In order to do that let us make certain confessions.

The first is that the critical 
                 
                  atttiude
                  attitude
                 
                 pinches the mind.
It is no longer fitting. This is partly due to the
it pinches; it compresses; It puts the mind in whalebones,

like a stays, or 
                  picnhes
                  pinches
                 the foot like too tight shoes.

Even to copy 
                  accura ely
                  accurately
                 a quotation breaks the 
                  st eam
                  stream
                 of
thought. The need of accuracy is again inimical. In short,
the critic today is is like a in the position of a

body 
                  owhich
                  which
                 feels the attraction of many magnets at
one and the same time.

To demagnetise 
                  ourlves
                  ourselves
                 we have to shut the book;
If we can, let us be aware only of the   and to seek if we
can find it a state of mind that is propitious; that state
of mind which in which it seems possible to us to write the

book, not to read it. In that state of mind 
                  fu 
                  full
                 of 
                  impresion
                  impressions

incordinated
                  uncoordinated
                , contradictory, 
                  i
                  in
                 which so many 
                  sneses
                  senses
                 seem to
take part; and yet one or two gradually become significant.

Here we are trying to 
                    disover
                    discover
                   what the source of the sunk

impulse. And the 
                  didden
                  hidden
                 spring, the gush of water

deep 
                    beanth
                    beneath
                   the mud. Whether it holds true universally, or

if not, the 
            fi st
            first
           instinct is to be
